{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3494058,"name":"","username":"TheBatman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thebatman/{size}/255139_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-27T21:27:31.383Z","cooked":"

My team is using a Kraken x60 motor to power an arm, we plan on using the in built magic motion to allow for precise control, while researching it we discovered a problem, the absolute encoder we use for the arm is a Rev Through Bore Encoder, and we dont have any CANCoders available.
As we understand there isnt a way to have the motor get it’s sensor measurements from the through bore encoder.
We originally planned to use plain rotations without converting it inside the motor (only convert the value of the through bore encoder to the value the kraken should expect and set it at the start), but because the feedforward formula for an arm mechanism has Kg * cos(theta), we have to have theta as the angle of the arm and not in rotations.

How can we convert the rotations in the motor to the angle (assuming we have the gear ratios and all that).

  • We noticed in the FeedbackConfigs class the value - “SensorToMechanismRatio”, but it is stated that it shouldn’t be used so we are unsure about it
","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-01-27T21:27:31.383Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":112,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":588.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":483852,"topic_slug":"converting-units-in-inner-talonfx-encoder","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71857,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Vigilante"},"post_url":"/t/converting-units-in-inner-talonfx-encoder/483852/1","custom_user_title":"Vigilante","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3494359,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-28T02:11:39.196Z","cooked":"

In this case, you can use SensorToMechanismRatio since you’re not using a CANcoder. However, since you’re not using a remote CANcoder, you must ensure that you have some kind of zeroing procedure set up, as the motor position must report 0 when the arm is horizontally forward. It’s also important that you get the gear ratio correct, and the system should have minimal backlash.

In your case, since you have a REV Through Bore Encoder, you could do an initial sync of the motor position to the encoder’s position on program startup instead of having a manual zero procedure. Otherwise, the zeroing procedure can be something like a limit switch at the lower extreme of motion, or a button to reset the position to a known value.

Side note, besides using CANcoders, you can also use a CANdi to put up to two absolute sensors onto the CAN bus. Then you can directly use that as a remote sensor source.

Should the motor position that we set be in degrees or in radians?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-01-28T13:56:45.073Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":98,"readers_count":97,"score":34.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":483852,"topic_slug":"converting-units-in-inner-talonfx-encoder","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":48146,"username":"bhall-ctre","name":"Benjamin Hall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71857,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Vigilante"},"post_url":"/t/converting-units-in-inner-talonfx-encoder/483852/3","custom_user_title":"Vigilante","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3494778,"name":"Cory","username":"TytanRock","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tytanrock/{size}/167849_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-28T16:12:09.635Z","cooked":"

The setPosition method takes an Angle object, so you can construct the angle object using whatever units you want.

For example:

motor.setPosition(Radians.of(Math.PI));
motor.setPosition(Degrees.of(180));
motor.setPosition(Rotations.of(0.5));

All do the same thing.

So if want to print/log the angle of the arm in degrees how do i get it in degrees.
Also a bit of topic but if i also have an elevator mechanism, with a kraken x60 motor (in my case two but 1 follows the other) and again with a rev through bore encoder.
When i reset the motor sensor value do i give it as a plain double value of the height the elevator is currently at or how do i work with it?

m_LeftMotor.getPosition().getValue().in(Degree)

Not sure it is the best answer, but I use rotations and convert it to distance. In theory by using the circumference of whatever is driving the elevator. In practice we move the elevator a specific distance, note the beginning and ending rotations and calculate a ratio. And when the empirical research dictates it, we just note the “notable” locations and how many rotations are at that specific spot.

Should they be in radians or degrees or something else completely.
